There may also have been some murmurings of the high chair only being an option at the tables in the back in order to avoid fire hazards; i think there are probably some staggeringly simple solutions to that particular problem but the place is still in its infancy so maybe they'll figure it out...or maybe it's an intentional policy to prevent the place from turning into a crèche. Hard to say.The food - we had the egg sandwich, ranchero omelette, scrambled eggs and potato hash.  It was perfectly ok but a little underwhelming. It just seems like standard diner fare but smaller portions. One exception - the scrambled eggs were superb! Some of the best scrambled eggs i've had since the Caravan back in London. Also to be fair some of the dinner options (like the sliders) look very good.It's a great space for a coffee and i'd go back again for the eggs and to try the dinner options.

Nice new place for a quiet brunch.  Nice service and great staff. So happy that they moved into this neighborhood.I went in with two other friends and we ordered different food from the Brunch menu and everything we order was excellent. Next time I will try lunch or dinner..will be back to let everyone know!

- MORE LIKE 3.5 STARS -Space and Experience-Nickel & Diner has been added into my friend and my latest must-try brunch spot for its modern decoration and delicious-looking dishes. We were prepared for a half hour to an hour wait on Sunday afternoon. However, the waiter said it'd only take like 25 mins which was good. The waiter (kinda gave me the typical" I AM SO FASHION and I ONLY shop at SOHO" kind of feeling....) -,-   asked if we wanted to sit at the corner bar area but couldn't switch to the table if it opened up. So we ended up ordering coffee at the front sitting area. While we were sipping our coffee and juice, another waiter came up and asked if we'd like to sit at the bar, and we could switch to the table area if available. I think that they need more internal communications.. otherwise we would deftly sit at the bar first. This kinda confused us. We finally got seated, but in the inner area where the tables were black with chairs and the space wasn't as opening and modern...which was kind of disappointing for meFood-We ordered a kale cashew salad, a classic egg sandwich, roasted maitake mushrooms, and a parmesan fries.1. The Kale cashew salad was warm and flavorful! The soft boil egg was cooked perfectly with the egg yolk running through the entire bowl, bringing all the ingredients together!! I hope there was a lil more cashew to add more crunchiness!2. To me, the Classic egg sandwich was more like standard. Pretty filling3. I love the the roasted maitake mushrooms! I liked the use of melted provolone, which didn't take over the mushrooms flavor at all! Also, my favorite was actually the heirloom rotatouille! which added the acidity and sweetness to the dish. YUM!4. The parmesan fries was crispy and delicious! The delicious food bumped up the score for the service part so it came up to 3.5.

Disappointed in our experience here. We were really looking forward to trying the lox and everything bagel, but the waiter told us they were out of lox. It's pretty crazy for a place known for their brunch to run out of a main dish. We decided on the breakfast sandwich and cashew kale salad. The salad was outstanding! I definitely recommend it. The sandwich was tasty, but we were disappointed they wouldn't swap out the bun for an everything bagel given that they ran out of the lox. The waiter wasn't very friendly and seemed to have a bit of an attitude.  It's a cool spot but probably won't be back.
Got the eggs florentine Benedict. So good!! Great service from Zach. Great coffee, and their hot cocoa is A+

This was not what I was expecting.  I wanted truly authentic diner food, not it.  I'm not saying it wasn't good.  The food was good, service was good.  If you're looking for eggs and toast, this is not really the place.  The atmosphere is extremely modern and clean.  We arrived in between breakfast and lunch service and were told we could have coffee, but could not order food for 20 minutes. What?  Anyways, the food was good. Service was good.  I will not be returning.  It's not my cup of tea.
Quiet but lively spot for breakfast. The egg sandwich is killer and they have top notch coffee. It's an upscale diner concept. Service is nice and they do have outlets at the counter top.

If I had to grade Nickel & Diner for the aesthetic appeal alone, that would already be a 5-star rating. The black and white decor may seem incredibly minimalist, but don't worry, the booths are comfortable enough. You get to relax on a cushy seat while you're regaled with amazing food and drinks; their hot chocolate is amazing: none of that powdery artificial mess you'll find in most stores. Good service, great interior and amazing food. What's not to like?
Lovely and sleek.  All the items we ordered are delicious.  Got the miso roasted chicken side of fries.  Everything was perfect, the staff was friendly.  Can't wait to go back, it's BYOB.

Nickel & Diner is a treat in Chinatown. The decor is modern; from the tiles colors to the font on the menu. The space has been re-vamped from its $5 buffet predecessor with a ton of windows that allow a lot of great natural light. My friends and I had a 2pm reservation last Saturday for Brunch. We received great and attentive service, even with some of us arriving 30 minutes late.I had the Salmon Lox ($15) which was served on a pumpernickel everything bagel, cucumber, avocado, spinach and a side of hollandaise. I left nothing on my plate. It was delicious.My friend's Grilled Steakhouse Burger ($17) almost had me place in another order; it looked really delicious.I've already made another reservation for this Saturday with another friend. Cant wait to go back and get that burger!

Chic little diner. They don't have their liquor license yet so if you want a boozy brunch its BYOB baby. We came here for a birthday on a Sunday afternoon, and luckily there is a liquor store not too far away! I called ahead to let the staff know we would be celebrating a birthday, and when the dessert came all of the waitors joined in singing (and singing well!!). Super cute, great experience. The matcha latte was pretty and yummy & the cafe mocha was DELISH. Our table split the pancakes, such a nice treat!

This was a cute diner with a modern twist. We sat in the coffee shop area and enjoyed both the food and drinks. The service was really friendly too by both the hostess and the server.Not a place we'd be seeking out from across town but definitely a good neighborhood gem.
Really nice breakfast place. Went in right when they opened at 8 and had a spot on breakfast. Great coffee, great eggs Benedict and great service.

Before you settle into a booth, on the side there's a hook where you get to hang your coat! Isn't that dandy?Comfy large booths that are meant for 4 people even though we were just a party of two. It's a place with really nice ambiance, perfect for date night. Food was so damn delicious, but a bit on the pricier side for the portion. Loved the scallops and foie gras appetizer. Friend had the pork chop which was ridiculously tender and juicy like I'd never had before, so hands down, recommend getting this dish. I ordered the crab fettucine, which was tasty and saucy but again, super small portion for close to $20.Bill came out to be around $70 for three items. Excellent service!

Perfect coffee and lunch spot for jury duty. Only a couple blocks away on the same street with lots of different seating options: counter, booth, and a corner for bistro/cafe tables near the barista. Really great service without the excesses of soho overcrowding and overpricing. Soup was delicious with fresh herbs. Lots of places to hang your coat in the winter. Excited to keep enjoying this place!

First impression: what is this American diner doing in the middle of Chinatown? I believe the space used to house a popular Chinese restaurant for affordable eats. That being said, it's been completely transformed into a modern-ish "diner" (or rather a nice room with diner-style bar stools) with shining white tiles and light flooding through its giant windows. The vibe is perfect for brunch that's casual yet elegant. The menu is perfect for the same.Salmon Lox: one of my favorites, a filling and healthy dish with an awesome combo of spinach, cucumbers, avocado, and lox on an impressively good pumpernickel everything bagel (2 of my favorite bagels in 1!). It's near impossible to eat as a sandwich - eating it open-faced is the way to go. Roasted Maitake Mushrooms: the healthiest dish we ordered, mostly vegetables. The ratatouille has a nice zing, and maitake mushrooms are my favorite. Some grains or bread to soak up the sauce/egg yolk would've been a nice addition. Yummy but not very filling. Eggs Florentine: pretty standard, well executed with a fresh non-goopy hollandaise. Buttermilk Pancakes: larger than your face and really delicious. Bits of macadamia and hints of orange throughout perfectly-fluffy-yet-densely-satisfying pancakes, and a trio of toppings including one very cinnamony apple compote.Potato Hash: interestingly mixed with roasted red peppers and some gooey cheese, a decent carb side (would be perfect with the mushrooms!). I may go for fries next time.Sharing is highly recommended, so you can order a bit of everything for a well-rounded meal. I had my eye on the breakfast sandwich and burger, which seemed popular. Service was fine, and what I really appreciated was the faint jazzy background music and moderately quiet noise level. It's just what you need on a Sunday morning.

The rosemary/parm fries. Oh My God. Delicious. I also ordered their "blt" and it was weird. It was good but too cheesy. I asked for "blt" not "blt&c", so I didn't expect so much cheese. It's okay, I will comeback for the fries. I will probably ask them not to give me cheese if I order the sandwich again though. Would come back, pricey though.

Definitely recommend if you're in the area and looking for non-Chinese food. Chic space, i.e. a fun play on the American diner. And all of the food was a-okay. Nothing to write home about, but solid nonetheless. And a wide enough range of options for everybody's stupid dietary restrictions.Warning: the insta-perfect hot chocolate with homemade marshmallows was the most anticlimactic part of our meal. Tasted like Swiss Miss...

The food here is tasty! I had the kale cashew bowl and, aesthetically, it's beautiful. I felt full and energized after consuming this beautiful dish. The hot chocolate is something you should also consider ordering because it's thick and rich. The interior is fantastic and I might come back to dine once more.

Was at Nickel and Diner on Sunday for brunch and it was fabulous. I had the classic egg sandwich which was perfect. The Kaiser roll held the sandwich together and the flavors were not overshadowed by the bacon or cheese. I don't know why others had such  negative comments about the sandwich, I would order it again.  Will definitely go back again.

Came here on a Sunday afternoon for lunch. Wait time was about 20 minutes, though I'm not sure why cause when we were seated, there were plenty of open spots.. at least 8! Some open seats had dirty plates from the previous customer so it was obvious that they didn't clear those seats for waiting customers. Anyway, we were seated at the bar and first thing I noticed was how slow and unattentive the staff/waiters/waitresses were. It took about 20 min for us to order. I also noticed a bus boy who was standing there shinning the cups. I guess it's nice to get paid to do that.. lol I just couldn't help but notice how almost useless some of the staff were. Anyway onto the food, there's not much to select from the menu. It's pretty limited and it seems like everyone ordered the same thing cause there really isn't much to order. We got the burger, asked for medium rare. It came out super well done. Also ordered the most typical dishes (it appears), Brussels sprouts and chicken. Everything was very below mediocre. We ate just to eat and quickly got out. The only thing attractive about this place is the transformation from an old Rundown Chinatown buffet to a modern trendy lower east side meets Chinatown joint. Wouldn't recommend it and wouldn't ever come back. There are so many other spots in the city.

I brunched. I had coffee. & I bathed in the light of aesthetic minimalism.Sounds good right?! When I suggested to my boyfriend that we should come here, he asked me what the diner was known for ~ and I answered: the vibe. Yes, the food is pretty average, but if you're a basic Instagram girl who loves brunch, minimal vibes, and white backgrounds for your food pics, then you're in for a treat LOL.First of all, make a reservation online before coming! It's such a spacious diner with huge booths, so definitely go all out and make that family / friend-gathering brunch here! FOOD TRIED:- Roasted Maitake Mushrooms - mushroom lovers should definitely try this dish!- Grilled Steakhouse Burger - good burger but what stood out to me were the fries! I love me some nicely seasoned crispy fries.- Potato Hash - baked with cheese and some veggies, mmmm yes

What a weird place to have a diner at, on the end of Chinatown. If it wasn't for yelp I wouldn't know there's a diner located here. I am surprised by how instagram worthy the interior and the food is. I stepped in for brunch yesterday morning. I ordered eggs Benedict. My breakfast was great. The were made the way I liked. I didn't get to try the coffee yet since I already drank a cup on the way to the diner. Next time when I come back I will try the coffee and give a review update.

came here for dinner and to my surprise it was Not packed as I expected it to be. The waitresses are warming and welcoming. I ordered wild shrimp a la plancha and i loved how there was a taste of mango with chili oil. Overall I will be back.

I found this diner through yelp and surprised that it is 2 blocks away from where I work. I love how there are phone chargers everywhere! I came here for Lunch with co workers. I ordered the grilled BLT and shoestring fries. (BLT is quite pricey) my meal was pretty good and I enjoyed having lunch there.
Do not I repeat do not order the Rancheros Omelet it is a waste of money and your taste buds.

I love the drastic contrast between the Chinese exterior and the modern, Western diner interior. Nickle & Diner certainly knows how to decorate. However, to be honest, the large booths (though comfortable) seem a little bit of a waste of space. Meaning, it has the potential to seat  six people but more often it seats 3-4 people. If they were smaller they could fit more parties. Anyways, the food--the thing that matters most. My friends ordered the hot chocolate with the chocolate marshmallow. I tried a sip. It was so good! Not too sweet, not too bland. Only con: a little pricey (but what do you expect, it's NYC). We ordered the burger, the BLT, and the eggplant parmesan. Personally, I thought the eggplant parmesan was a little underwhelming. It would've been nice if it had a side that filled up more the dish or something that made it seem more worth it for what we were paying. BLT was pretty good, according to my friend. She particularly loved the truffle dressing on the salad. I ordered the burger, and I think I made the best choice. It was filling and rich with flavor. I loved the poppy seed bun!! We ordered the rosemary fries to share, which was a good portion, enough for 4 or more people. However, while there was a slight noticeable difference, it tasted rather similar to the regular fries that accompanied the burger dish. Everything was so filling. I came here a second time for the breakfast food. GET THE POTATO HASH. It's worth it. We got the eggs florentine and the egg sandwich. Both good, full of flavor and texture. I really loved how they balanced the flavors. Only complaint about the egg sandwich: the egg. It was neither poached nor boiled fully. It was rather confusing, maybe we were just unlucky with overcooked/undercooked egg.So overall, in terms of what to order, my favorites were the potato hash and the burger. There is a separate cafe at the entrance. So if you're only interested in drinks, there's that option.

For now this place is BYO, and paired with the excellent food, this is a recent favorite spot of mine.The only thing this place has to do with a diner is the modern, fresh interior which looks like the diner of the future. It really looks sharp. The food is nothing like diner-fare fortunately. I have ordered the pork chops and half chicken and both were superb. Well cooked, oozing with rich flavor and the fries, you must order the fries, there are a lot of them and they are sublime. My gf has ordered the beet salad twice now and greatly enjoyed it both times. A couple weeks ago, I organized a dinner of 7 people, planning to take advantage of the BYO policy while it was still in effect. Most restaurants would see seven 20 year olds with 4 bottles of wine and show a level of disapproval, but the staff here were very accomodating and did not make us feel like the hooligans we were for stretching the meaning of BYO. Our waiter the first time was perfectly polite and well-trained. The second was nice and chatted us up a bit but I could tell that he was new to the job and attempting, in a slightly infuriating fashion, to persuade us to order appetizers to share (as recent college graduates, we were not looking to break the bank). He went thru the menu, item by item, mentioning which were his favorites and it took him a few minutes. Hopefully he has excised this from his routine by now. High-quality food in a comfy setting with friendly and mostly adept waiters.

We were just in town for some college stuff and found this place one morning. When we found it we were a little bit skeptical of it because we just wanted some regular old American Breakfast food and it's in a predominantly Chinese area. When we got in, all our concerns were dispelled. This place has a really great atmosphere. It's sort of like a cross between an old 1950s diner and what I'd imagine a diner will look like in 2050. Very cool looking place. I had the eggs Benedict and my mom had the buttermilk pancakes both were amazing (but the Benedict was better). We also each had a cup of coffee which was great. I ordered a glass of fresh squeezed orange juice. A bit pricey but it's worth it for the fresh ingredients and friendly wait staff. We liked it so much we even came back a second time (tried the eggs Florentine. Also fantastic). My only disappointment was the cinnamon roll we had at the end. It wasn't bad, just not what I had expected from a place like this. Sorta dry. I'd highly recommend using some warm sauce on them or something. Definitely going back next time I'm in the city!

We came by today with my parents for lunch. We were seated right away in the back. The experience went went downhill from there. Since it was past 11, we were told no breakfast item will be served even though I really wanted to try the egg sandwich. Usually if you call yourself a diner, the menu is all day and I can't imagine how hard it would be to serve something on the breakfast menu. Also, we were told there is no kid menu and also they won't be able to serve the burgers in halves so we can share. The waitress had an attitude while taking our order and didn't offer to refill our water during the whole meal. The food was definitely above average, I enjoyed the fried chicken appetizer, the burger and the pasta dish. When we were checking out, I noticed our waitress added 20% service fee to our bill for 4 adults and a toddler. Usually I would be fine if the service is good, but I thought this time she got a bit presumptuous and also 20% for lunch is steep as an automatic service fee. This is the rare occasion when the service part really dragged down the entire experience. I will avoid that waitress at all cost next time if I ever go back which is quite unlikely.

Growing up in les, this is the first Americanized diner I've seen around. The interior is beautiful makes me want to go here for brunch everday. The coffee tasted better than many coffee spots. The breakfast here is good as well. Overall, I will be back.

I was here yesterday morning for brunch and it was packed like sardines. Happily we got a table within 45 mins wait. (A bit long but it's ok) as we sat down the waitress was very attentive. What I ordered was the salmon lox and coffee. They were pretty good. My date really liked his breakfast too. It was a good experience but will most likely be back when we are around here.

​Had a late brunch at Nickel & Diner with a couple friends this past Saturday.  The location is not great, but the restaurant itself is bright, modern, and comfortable.  I ordered the Kale Cashew Bowl (requested scrambled eggs versus poached).  It was healthy, hearty, and delicious - just wish there were actual cuts of sweet potato versus a puree.  The BF's BEC sandwich looked pretty darn good too.  Would come back once they get their liquor license!  ​
The food was amazing ! but be warned a small bottle of sparkling water is $6 !

The name is misleading - this is NOT a diner, (though it looks like one) and its not inexpensive. Stopped in for a light lunch while serving on jury duty and was surprised to find the menu is very limited and not diner-like at all. Snagged a seat at the bar and ordered a regular drip coffee, appetizer and a side. I don't know where the "nickel" in the name comes from-my meal was 23$!!! The service was fast and friendly, and the food was pretty good. However, when I went to use the restrooms they were out of order! Overall very disappointed with the menu variety, value, and facilities - would not go back.

Probably worth 5 stars, but I hit it at the breakfast-lunch transition.   Things dragged a bit. I had a truly beautiful waitress, a woman from another generation. Dark haired, stout-- I found her so hard not to stare at.   I had Ciabata toast-- which was ok, a bit too loaded with weak gardineirra.   So it all tastes a bit too pickled for me.  I'll go back and order something else.  I'll bet I love it.

Really enjoyed my morning at this breakfast spot. The runny, affordable, massive egg sandwich is by far the star of the show and you've gotta get it. Everything else is pretty good but this is Awesome. The atmosphere is quaint, clean and very spacious and pretty to dine in. Great way to give the Chinatown area a chance for brunch.

I have only been here for coffee but was impressed by the quality of cafe offerings, including pour-over. I had chai and a slice of poundcake, both were really good. Service and the space felt very inviting and well designed. I'll definitely be back.

Had a truly fantastic dinner at Nickel & Diner, so good I can't wait for others to discover this great new spot!Located on the underside of SoHo (Lafayette & Canal), it's in the heart of things and yet is still pleasantly tucked out of the chaos. The restaurant also includes a stand alone coffee shop open all day. The menu/hours recently extended to include breakfast, brunch, lunch and dinner service.My dinner experience was really fantastic. All around great service and a great experience that's clearly been thoughtfully designed by the owner and chef. The food was outstanding and the environment was unexpected casual perfection. Seems like a good spot for a friend gathering or date night...big booths with lots of space and very cool counter seating that is a smart update to diner dining. I ate a lot () and still have no regrets. Highly suggest trying some of the vegetable sides and apps that may not pop off the printed menu because...reasons. Some of the highlights:- slow roasted squash is a must- spicy shrimp a la plancha- tuna escabeche (wow...just wow!)- foie gras terrine is the best I've ever had- roasted mushrooms - lobster tortellini- beet salad- cavatelli gratin- fried chicken app Looking forward to a return visit to try the brunch menu and spending more time in the chill coffee shop. N&D is a great addition to the downtown dining scene and one that has clearly been designed to create a great experience for all. Well done.

Came here for lunch on a Thursday with friends and was seated immediately in a booth. The diner is very simple, clean, and modern in terms of aesthetics and the staff are friendly. I tried the hot chocolate with the chocolate marshmallow which was really good and not overly sweet (was a tad pricey though). I ordered the blt which was smothered in cheese and delicious; the salad is tossed in a truffle dressing which was also very good. My friends and I also ordered the rosemary fries which comes in a generous serving (even though it looks small in the picture)! We had trouble finishing it amongst the 3 of us and they did not disappoint.We'll be coming back again to try the breakfast menu!

Made reservations ahead of time. They were very accommodating and helpful. Our server, Erica, was very nice at the start and helpful in answering questions about the menu. We ended up ordering two egg sandwiches and fries to share, as sides are separate orders (which bumps the price tag up a little). Our server got our order wrong and only brought us one egg sandwich and fries to share. We didn't really notice until 20 minutes longer of waiting and then asked her and she seemed quite peeved. The food, itself, was VERY salty. I was downing cups of water. The fries were extremely salty and the egg sandwich, which had a very tasty bun, was nothing I couldn't make at home and doused in salt. Upon leaving we asked to split the check, at which point our server rolled her eyes and said she had too much going on to split the check. We said it was no problem and we would venmo each other, already quite put off. We were making train plans about 5 minutes after paying and the server came by telling us we had to leave because we were holding up the line (there was only one group waiting). Overall, not impressed. The location is pretty uncharming, the food is uninspired, and the service is lacking.
This restaurant has a nice decor.  the coffee was just right for me. The brunch was amazing. Especially being in Chinatown it's hard to find an area with a total different taste of food.

Super cute place, I live for cute décor. Came here with some friends since we got hungry, ordered the pork chop, smaller portions than a typical diner but was still very good. Ordered appetizers that were tasty as well. The service was nice, friendly crowd, nice environment. Will come back again most likely if im in the area and have this craving.
I actually worked around the area and came here for brunch. I ordered coffee and salmon box. It was a bit pricey but it tasted good. The food was good I can't complain. Will visit again!
Came here for brunch this morning I was pleased with my food. I really enjoyed the latte and the pancakes. Service was amazing. Thank you

This rating is for the food because it was delicious and portion size was great for brunch. The burger and BLT were so delicious and the BLT tasted like pizza, lol and had a nice little side salad. The burger was also delicious, and cooked perfectly. The service was so/so. The water was always being refilled, but I asked a number of people for more coffee instead of being asked.

Lovely food, service is another story.Walked into Nickel & Diner with my party and was greeted by a lovely host and wished he was the one who serviced us that day. Sadly no, and that's why this review has a lower rating.Our waitress, a ginger woman, whom had a very sarcastic attitude from the start, did not make us feel welcomed. We decided to just brush it off and enjoy our meal but over time, her attitude and actions just made our stay worse. At one point, she threw my straw at me instead of handing it or settling it down the table. Everyone was just outraged at this point. Would come here for the steakhouse burger again but if she were to service me, I'm immediately calling the manager this time.Update:Decided to come here again for brunch/lunch. Service was lovely since our waitress/waiter was different from the ginger woman.

first off our waiter kinda looked like a young seth rogen AND he was hilariousi've been dying to try this place because of its 'instaworthyness' and a lot of times trendy places are worth the photos but not worth the taste. however this place was delicioso and i will be eating here again.my friend got the grilled steakhouse burger; she said it was super juicy! i got the grilled blt which is served on sourdough with smoked bacon, heirloom tomato, and truffle vinaigrette. this was theeee fanciest blt i've ever had and it didn't even look like a blt. it tasted like a pizza it was sooo yummy! it required a knife and fork to eat so you know it's fancy. we ordered the mac and cheese on the side and it was pretty good too but nothing too spectacular. we wanted to order fries but being just the two of us it was going to be way too much food. will definitely be back! maybe next time for brunch :)

Meh. I've experienced better.This place has been sitting here for a while, but only recently did they start doing dinner, which I went for.Arrived at 8:30 PM and tried to get a booth, but was unsuccessful as they told us we needed to reserve them. As the night went on, the place got pretty crowded, despite it being a Wednesday.My friend ordered the carrots and potato and celery puree, with an appetizer of fried chicken, which was laughably small. I got the fries with the pork chop. The portions here were quite small, and quite the pork chop was cooked just fine, they threw some sort of spice/flavor on the pork chop that was very distinct, and kind of ruined the whole flavor. Fries were fine, but it's not too difficult to mess that up.This is a pretty clean establishment and a welcome addition to the greater Chinatown area, but the thing is this place isn't really a "Diner" at all as far as dinner goes (which is kind of misleading). It has the words diner, but the dinner menu suggests that this is more of a typical contemporary American restaurant. Don't expect to get patty melts, milkshakes, or any of that kind of typical 'Diner' food.While overpriced, I do understand that making the rent at this location must be tough. This place is fairly notorious, and though it wasn't a wholly positive experience, I hope they do well. I may come back for breakfast or coffee, but not for dinner, as the prices aren't really worth paying for the food offer.
Everything (brussel sprouts & Shishito peppers, French fries, burger & Mac & cheese) was absolutely derisious....Top that off w/attentive staff.....Yessss...

A friend and I stopped in to Nickel & Diner on a dreary Sunday morning to give their brunch a try on the suggestion of a friend. We had never heard of the place and it had just had it's soft opening a week prior.We were in for a pleasant surprise and it's a place I will have no problem recommending to people in the future. We ordered the Classic Egg Sandwich and the Grilled Steakhouse Burger with a side of Potato Hash. The burger was excellent (not overly cooked and juicy and flavorful) and the egg sandwich was fantastic (the eggs were great with the basil vinaigrette). We couldn't even finish the Potato Hash because we were so full, not for lack of trying though as it was good too.The diner itself had a great atmosphere and ambience. It was spacious so I never felt cramped like you might with other restaurants in NYC.Overall, a great experience all around and I'm definitely going to have to come back here to try the rest of the menu.

Recommended by two close friends and was informed that food was awesome. Came here with a friend  for breakfast, I had a great omelette (it was fluffy and favorful) and my friend had the two poached egg (don't remember the name) - it was on point! (Perfection). I will recommend this place to my fellow food buddies! A place I will come, eat and relax!

Perhaps brunch is better but lunch was awful. I had the fried chicken app, which tasted stale and flavorless, and the Brussels sprouts, which lacked imagination. I cook better than this which isn't saying much for this place. I'm a terrible cook.

Nickel & Diner is the brainchild of a diner and a minimalist. My bf and I were wandering around chinatown and came upon this newly opened restaurant. Booth waiting was 20 mins so we opted to sit at the bar. We ordered the Mac n cheese (not called Mac n cheese on the menu but something with gratin); the steak burger and the chicken soup. Service took awhile and we waited 20 minutes for the food hence -1 star. Everything tasted delicious and I especially loved the rosemary fries that came with the burger. Although a bit pricey, you certainly get the quality that you pay for.  Not to mention the service was impeccable, waiters were attentive and constantly cleaning the counter and refilling waters.
I had the sliders and the brusselsprouts. Both were very good! I just feel the menu is too small. Wish they had a few more options. I do like the space, pretty cool.

Since I drive a limo, I wanted to find the closet place to where my client was. So I saw the word diner and walk in. Well to say the least, this is not your typical diner. The menu is very limited and I was told that this was more of an upscale diner. Did not know they existed, but alas I found one. Had the pork chop and potatoes. Was actually very good. However, I was the only person in my area on a Tuesday night at 7pm. Should have been no reason for slow service, since I was your only customer until 10 minutes ago. Ambience is very hipster and I would assume on a Thursday or Friday night this place would jumping. Nice date place during the week since I don't know what the weekend is like yet. So other than slow service on a Tuesday night with only 5 people inside, the place is great.

The interior of the place was gorgeous but the food didn't match up. We came here for lunch on a Tuesday, and it was mostly empty. The food was mediocre and didn't have much flavor. Was really disappointed because the place is beautiful but the food doesn't match up!
loved the egg sandwich, the ham and bacon was great!
Love this new diner in Chinatown area! Got their cappuccino and kaffir lime tart&it was so delicious!  Friendly staff would definitely come back again!!

Wow their food was delicious. I came in the morning today and had the omelette. I took a gamble on this and good thing I had it. The portion was big and it was delicious. The latte I got was strong and beautiful. Felt bad I had to drink it. I'll definitely be back for my morning breakfast.

Only reason I'm giving this 2 stars is because it had good food & was BYOBOn a Saturday we waited 1.5 hrs, when they told us 45 minutes. IThey ran out of orange juice.They didnt come to our table once we were seated for at least 15 minutes

Was a little surprised when the place was really empty for our saturday night reservation. But then we realized--no liquor license yet! BYOB is always a nice surprise and makes for a relatively inexpensive meal. I'm sure it's packed for brunch, but don't sleep on the dinner service--it was great! I was very pleasantly surprised by all the food although the service was pretty slow (yet friendly). I guess they are still working out some kinks!You can skip the artisanal bread and butter, but the fried chicken, and the short rib were to die! The lobster pasta, sea bass, and farro risotto were good as well. Get the peanut butter cake and soft serve for dessert.
Steak burger and their fries with some kush beforehand.

Went to this diner yesterday with two friends. We called ahead and were given a 20 minute wait... It turned into an hour wait after we arrived.  We had coffee while we were waiting which was nice.  Once we finally were seated, service was very slow. We had to go back to the counter for more coffee after asking numerous times.  I ordered the BLT which was NOT a BLT at all {tomatoes on top of the bread which made it difficult to eat}.  My friend had the omelet which seemed to be made of one egg, and a small strip of ham with some chopped tomatoes. {$15!} My other friend had the sweet potato bowl which was good.  The French fries were outstanding! Overall, a subpar experience and we won't be returning.

Oddly situated within the bounds of Chinatown, but I loved the feel as I walked in - a sleek, clean, modern day diner that's spacious enough to comfortably fit the long counter running the length of the space and banquettes lining the perimeter.The weekend brunch menu is divided into salads, eggs, and sandwiches, with most options falling within the great price range of $10-15. I went for the classic egg sandwich - hickory smoked bacon, sharp cheddar, fried eggs, ham - per recommendation by my server and added on a side of fries to make it extra healthy. The sandwich turned out to be good but ok - tasty, filling, but not quite to the point where your mind consciously registers "hey pay attention, this is good stuff". The kaiser roll was too soft to support the weight of the sandwich, especially when it became soggy from the spread and egg yolk; I wouldn't have noticed the supposedly sharp cheddar if it weren't visibly melted onto the bacon; the bacon tasted like normal bacon to me - didn't hint at much hickory smoked flavor.The thin fries came with a liberal sprinkle of parmesan and herbs on top, but personally speaking, I would've loved if the cheesiness/herbiness were on all the fries, not just the top ones!Can't fight the price point though - I paid $15 for the entire meal and even though it wasn't fully satisfying, I still came out of it feeling like I'd just gotten an awesome deal.So - 3.5 stars on food, but service, vibe, and price push it up to 4.

Stopped in to Nickel & Diner for a very late brunch one chilly winter weekend. All tables were full but there were seats available at the bar. This place is an upscale, high-end diner so don't come expecting a greasy spoon. All the patrons surrounding us were NY chic. The food is good but overly expensive. The burger topped with cheese and fried onion was cooked perfectly and topped with a delicious aioli. The BLT was too messy in my opinion and fell apart on the plate. However, the taste was great and the salad was tossed in a TRUFFLE dressing. That's how you know you've made it in the world - when salad tastes like a tasty morsel of truffle.Would return to try menu options at a different meal, such as breakfast or dinner.
Newly openned diner extremely close to where i currently live. Food was great. I really like what i ordered. Coffee was good as well. Good vibes and great service. Ill be be soon.

first review for yelp. i found this diner through facebook. i decided to try it. im excited that they have red hook coffee here. the brunch here may get packed sometimes and there might be a wait. overall will i had a good experience. hopefully they will have a signature dish.

New diner on the borderline of Little Italy, Soho and Chinatown, right on the corner of Howard and Centre. My friend had told me about this new diner that had recently opened. Perhaps our expectations were high but My friend and I left very disappointed. You walk into the entrance on Centre St., the host will be on your right and in front of you, you will notice a nice coffee station serving up Nobletree coffee from Redhook Brooklyn. Five and dime counters with fixed diner bar stools. Large, bright windows with spacious and comfy booths. The host offered us a nice spacious booth. The server was repressive and did not seem into the job even though it was not that busy. The server took our order then left the table. When the food came, the server asked if we needed anything and we declined. After digging into my meal, the server did not come by to check on us. Not that I needed supervision but I was ready to speak up if he would come and check on the table. The food was sadly disappointing. Less than mediocre. I was honestly not planning to touch the food and see if the server would stop by and check our satisfaction. The other staff members even hawked over my table many times because they have noticed that i was not touching the food anymoreIt is a huge red flag if your customers order only a few items and not even finishing one fourth of each dish. But nope, no questions, concerns or interactions. Distastefully, did not even bother to give desserts a try. Table was just cleared, check was paid and on my way to out to quickly find another place to grab a fast lunch at before work. The burger was super dry and bland. I had asked for the burger to be medium rare and the burger came medium well, was there a miscommunication there? did the server ask for the wrong temperature or the chef not know how to make a burger medium rare? The brussel sprouts and shishito peppers had a weird herbaceous taste. Not sure how I feel about these two items mixed together. The cavatelli could use some salt, actually a lot of salt but unfortunately that did not save it either, just super bland. I was excited for their shoestring fries, nothing about it tasted exciting, not think enough either. Even the coffee was too acidic. There must be some spectacular item on the menu that I would want to try for me to return.

Growing up in the tri-state area, I frequented Chinatown weekly as a child as my grandparents spent most of their time there.  As long as I can remember, this spot used to be a Chinese fast casual quick service spot.  Then one day, Nickel & Diner took over.  It's sad that old school spot are disappearing, but at the same time, this area gets another taste of American food.  My party of two came in for Sunday brunch at 2pm.  There were plenty of seats, and reservations were not even needed.  Just as you enter, there is a coffee bar area to grab a coffee to-go or sit down to chat or do a little work.  Then, you enter the dining area where we were seated.  We ordered the Classic Egg Sandwich ($8) and Salmon Lox Bagel ($14).  The Classic Egg Sandwich delivered!  The Sandwich may seem small, but the taste and the heaviness of the dish fill you up.  The Bagel was also good, but very difficult to eat.  It is nicely presented on an open faced bagel, but all the ingredients fall off once you take your first bite.  This dish needs to be better constructed!  Definitely not a date food as you'll be caught trying to catch your falling sandwich.  All in all, the food was good, but nothing mind blowing.  It is a solid brunch meal that doesn't break the bank.  But then again, you can just go to your corner deli and pick up the egg sandwich or lox bagel!

My sister recommended me to try this diner. The service here is great. The food as well. I came here for brunch and it was packed. The pancakes were so fluffy. Coffee comes from Noble tree, it's so goood. Forget Starbucks that's around the corner. Nickel and diner will be my regular stop-in for morning coffee.

Was around the neighborhood when a friend of mine pointed out this diner. The hot chocolate was delicious and not overwhelmingly sweet, warmed us up immediately. If you are a salmon lover like myself,  the salmon lox is definitely a must! But the star of the meal was the key lime pie. My friend and I even contemplated on ordering one more! Great service, will for sure come back.

Popped in on a Saturday for brunch. Definitely a great find in the heart of Chinatown. Food was beautifully presented and delicious. Must try their buttermilk pancake!! Overall the atmosphere was cozy and waiters were friendly. Would come back to try more of their food.

I got a casual dinner here with friends and was surprised at the amazing gluten free options! We ordered almost half the menu with 7 other friends. Everything was delicious - my favorites being the grilled lobster and new croquettes.  Staff was attentive and friendly as well.  It's not super packed right now because they just opened a month ago but that won't be till very long. Oh also try the coffee! It's Nobletree coffee and in my opinion better than la Colombe - I've started buying my coffee to go at the counter here in the mornings.
Great place. It was close by and I enjoy eating here. The staffs are well mannered and friendly. I strongly recommend this place. The food is amazing too.

Decent but was expecting a bit more from this place. I didn't leave here feeling satisfied that I had a good meal. We ordered the eggplant parm sandwich, reuben, and burger. The reuben was the best choice out of the three. I was definitely expecting the eggplant parm to have much more flavor. The bread to eggplant/sauce ratio definitely another reason why it missed the mark. As for the burger, they did a decent job but nothing to write home about.

ordered deep fried eggplant sandwich, about 15 bucks.3 star to the deep fried eggplant, blended well with the dressing. The watercress was fresh n good. The melted cheese added additional flavor .2 star deducted from the bread, it was not fresh, it was dried n hard. kind of disappointing.**this restaurant has good menu contains vege-only choices, n meat-lover choices.they make good coffee too.my friend tried their espresso said it was good.**it a new fresh look restaurant in the neighborhood, i will come back n try others things on the menu.

What a cute and CLEAN place! The moment you walk in, you know you stepped into a modern diner. The service was great - the waitress was very attentive and made sure to check on us without being too pushy. We ordered the classic egg sandwich which was okay in my opinion. I got the roasted maitake mushrooms which I really liked - full of flavor and a good healthy salad with it. I wish the dish was bigger though - I still felt a little hungry afterwards. I also got the hot chocolate with the chocolate marshmallow. I wouldn't recommend this simply because it was a little cold and the marshmallow wouldn't melt. The waitress asked me how it was, and when I was honest, she agreed with me and said that she would work with the restaurant to think of how to tweak it.  Constructive criticism taken with appreciation - now that's good service!

Decent.  Not great.  The decor is modern, actually a bit too modern.  It would have been nice if they peppered in some classic diner design.  Also the music playlist leaves much to be desired.  I am not trying to listen to some bumping hip hop at 11 am eating breakfast and drinking my coffee.  The identity of this place is confusing to me.  It seems like they are trying to go for a super sleek European modern feel with a clubby vibe, in the heart of Chinatown...On to the menu.  I have never been to a diner with a single page menu.  Every diner I have been to has had an overstuffed menu chock full of laminated pages with pictures of food photographed in the 80s.  Case in point, I would have appreciated a few more options and a little more variety.  The food was decent.  My steakhouse burger was juicy and flavorful and the fries were very crunchy, so no complaints there.  The potato hash wasn't great, once you got past the crunchy top layer with cheese, it was a sad mosh pit of soggy potatoes with no seasoning.  My girlfriend's egg sandwich was big but lacking a lot of flavor.  I can't comment on my friend's salads because I don't have any interest in salads. The most interesting part of this brunch was seeing the sweet Chinatown local ladies peer into the windows to see what was going on, most likely wondering what happened to the $5 buffet that preceded this restaurant.  Another sad reminder of increasing gentrification...going from $5 buffet to $17 burgers...For whatever reason, the stools that wrap the bar area are on a raised platform.  There were a couple of instances where a few patrons tripped over the raised corner of the platform.  Luckily no one fell or got hurt.  Definitely a poor design choice.  The service was the highlight of the experience.  Our waters and coffees were always full and our waiter was very accommodating and friendly. Feelings on this place:Do I feel clean?  Yes.  Do I feel sexy?  Not any more than I did coming in.  Does the food taste good?  Depends on who you ask, but I would say yes.  Will I come back?  Most likely not.
This is probably one of my favorite brunch spots! The wait isn't long and the staff is amazing there. Would definitely come back!!!

I spotted Nickel & Diner's clean/sexy decor on my way to the MoCA, and after some quick Googling decided to check it out after my museum visit. I was drawn in both by the beautiful interior design and the Chikarashi pedigree -- Chikarashi is my absolute favorite poké spot in NYC. I think Nickel & Diner probably runs a stronger brunch/lunch game than dinner, though my dinner here (during its opening week) was solid. They weren't doing anything revolutionary with their dinner dishes, whereas their brunch menu seems to provide higher quality fare than a lot of places in Manhattan that are just phoning it in. The waitstaff were all attentive, kind, and helpful -- though they weren't able to mitigate the odd timing of the kitchen (we got our dishes all out of order). And like Chikarashi, these dishes are all Instagram-ready. There's a nod to Chinatown in a few of the dishes, which seems fitting, given the location. We liked but didn't loooove the bok choy stir fry, and found the foie gras + diver scallops ($16) rich but not especially complex (both of these meats are sumptuously textured but didn't play well off each other). The roasted mushroom side was disappointingly devoid of salt, though that didn't hide the natural umami flavor of the fungi. The acorn squash was delightfully autumnal but ultimately a bit too sweet, and the shrimp was probably the best-spiced dish but even so, wasn't the most memorable restaurant shrimp we'd had recently. I felt that every dish needed a little more excitement; mostly, they felt like the small plates that every somewhat upscale, trendy restaurant in Manhattan is serving now. In the end, the food just wasn't all that memorable. New American/elevated classics is already done well in NYC, and I can't say that Nickel & Diner really bucks the genre. At least with Chikarashi, they were able to make their mark known in a relatively uncrowded market, but with Nickel & Diner, they have a lot of competition.
Great sliders and soup! Love the atmosphere and the area. Dessert was awesome as well.

Decided to try this place because of a friends recommendation. I love the marble table by the entrance. I have some Instagram worthy pictures taken with that table haha. Now onto the food I ordered the sea bass and my boyfriend ordered the lobster. The seabass was cooked well with flavors and you cannot complain about the lobster. It was great. Every time we eat out we always have to order dessert and so we decided to try the apple cake. All I can say that the cake was YUMMMM YUMMM!

Came here on Sunday and it was packed. I waited about 15 minutes for brunch. As we sat down the waitress were very attentive to our wants. I love the buttermilk pancake and the delicious hot chocolate with a melted marshmallow. My friend got the eggs with mushroom it was delicious as well. Love the way they made the mushroom. We ended the meal with the keylime tart, and I absolutely LOVE THE DESSERT!

I heard about this diner had opened 5 blocks away from where I worked and I finally decided to go try it. I ordered the pork chop and the burger. It was really good! It was well made and fries were super tasty. Service was great and I enjoyed the food here. I probably might be a Regular here

So I ordered the Ranchero Omelette expecting a delight. I was fairly disappointed with the meal. The eggs were too runny, the Serrano ham just didn't quite fit well into the omelette from a taste perspective (clashing tastes I think). I'm no food expert by any means but it was a bland meal overall. I also ordered a cappuccino that came warm (instead of hot) so I had to drink it quickly before it got cold.My friend ordered scrambled eggs, bacon, and the potato hash sides and seemed to be content with the meal. The potato hash wasn't bad, but not amazing by any means.The two stars are the for the vibe (nice clean modern diner) and the waitstaff's kindness and and attentiveness.

Walked in on a Saturday morning.  The place was not particularly inviting--the sterile decor made it look more like an Urgent Care Center.  The joint was practically empty.  The hostess asked if we had made a reservation.  We hadn't so she escorted us to the counter even though there were plenty of available booths.  My wife asked if we could have a booth.  The answer was, No!  We had to have made a reservation.  Seated on my uncomfortable wooden counter stool, II glanced at the menu.  The brunch offerings were meager.  The wooden stool was uncomfortable.  I was pissed and feeling like a second class citizen.  It wasn't the hostess's fault, but, frankly, her manner was not particularly inviting.  We felt unwelcome and left.

My wife and I love NYC brunch. At least once a month. So when this opened recently, we were very happy. I read the new reviews, they were mixed but mostly positive, so I made my reservation.When:  Saturday morning in Nov. Right when it openedVibe:  I really liked the place. Nice interior, new but retro at the same time. Very spacious and welcoming, especially with all the big windows. Food:  We were very excited. I got the Ranchero omelette and my wife got the kale cashew bowl. She thought the bowl was ok. Decent flavor and satisfying, but not something she would crave.  My omelette on the other hand was a little disappointing. I read the description and was preparing myself for a flavor extravaganza! Sadly, I got an average omelet that barely had any of the ingredients inside. I'm not expecting a giant overstuffed egg dish, but I want the correct ratio of omelet-to-stuff inside. The coffee was very good though, but  the mugs are a little too small. Service:  Ok, not pleased here. Yes, I know they are new. But all the more reason to be giving each guest the attention they deserve. We were seated and maybe only 8 other people in the whole place at the time. We got our coffee, and placed our order. Then shortly needed a refill. Our server didn't check on us until way after our food was delivered. I even had to ask for more coffee, with two empty mugs on the table. I absolutely hate lukewarm coffee. Or no coffee. And never asked us how the food was, just seemed disinterested. Overall:  Nice place, decent food, poor service. So far. It's new and I am guessing that things will improve. I really hope so and they don't just rely on the public excited about a new restaurantIt's close to us so I think we'll try again.  Jmx

I lived in the Little Italy/Soho area for almost 4 years, and wouldn't you know it that as soon as I moved a little farther east, an awesome upscale diner opened two blocks from my former front door. It's still within a short walk of my current apartment, but had they opened a little sooner, they'd have been seeing me darn near every day. Some may call it a sign of gentrification in a predominately Chinese neighborhood, but I say they filled a much needed gaping hole in the market. They're fully open for breakfast, lunch, and dinner (after a hard stop at lunch), but so far I've only had a chance to try a fantastic breakfast sandwich. Hickory smoked bacon and country ham, two fried eggs, sharp cheddar, and basil vinaigrette on a kaiser roll, it was a step up from the classic deli BEC, but with many more bells and whistles. And at $8, it's a lot less that some of the other elevated breakfast sandwiches going around the city. In a slick setting with good music and beautiful people, it seems like it's only a matter of time until this place is a mainstay.

This place opened up about a month ago, and I've already been twice. It has definitely gotten a bit more crowded, but we were able to walk right in at peak brunch time and get a spot at the bar. The best way to describe it is a "fancy diner". I've come here twice, both times for a post-workout breakfast. It's definitely nice having a casual spot with some better-than-casual food.The bacon egg and cheese is a must. The hickory smoked bacon and basil sauce give it a distinct flavor that sets it apart from a typical breakfast sandwich. It's $8, which is a bit on the expensive side, but it's worth it. I have also had the kale and asparagus bowl which I would highly recommend for a healthy and satisfying option. This was around $13. Food is great, atmosphere is perfect for a casual meal, and the price is right. I will certainly be back, and am very glad to have found a casual but tasty spot right in my neighborhood!

I was impressed!   This new venue in NOCA (North of Canal, everyone's saying it) really put in the effort and time to deliver a solid impression on its customers and it worked on me.  Must tries: The fried chicken has a unique Asian flavored cripy skin; The scallop and foir gras (their version of a surf and turf) is a steal for the price.    I would recommend the steak or the pork for the entree... whatever you do, Do NOT forget the bone! It's arguably the most delicious part.  Their Squash dish is out of this world.I truly had a great time there.  Oh forgot to mention, super generous portion desserts if you have the stomach for it... we will be back!

Nickel & Diner is an old-school meets modern diner in Chinatown.My friends and I (4 of us), made a reservation for Saturday, 2:15pm. We were placed in a booth comfortable for 4, but you can definitely squeeze in 6. I really love the interior of this place. Clean and minimal. The details on the tables and walls adds a really nice touch to the dining experience.We ordered the kale cashew bowl, roasted maitake mushrooms, classic egg sandwich, shoestring fries, and hot chocolate. My friends really enjoyed their dishes and had only great things to say about them (kale cashew bowl and classic egg sandwich, I didn't try either). The roasted maitake mushrooms is soooo delicious! Everything combined together was just an amazing explosion of flavor in my mouth. The maitake mushrooms had the right texture and was very juicy. The fries are delicious and totally sharable.The hot chocolate was really delicious after our meal. The chocolate marshmallows are placed on the side and super delicious. At first, I felt that the hot chocolate did not have enough flavor, but after the marshmallow melted, it was very delectable. My friends tried to order alcohol, and then tea but they don't have either. Our waitress said they're in the process of acquiring a liquor license. My friend did order the cold brew and really loved it.The service here was pretty great. Our waitress was attentive and nice.Nickel & Diner is an awesome new brunch spot, and I am definitely coming back again. It is delicious and relatively cheap!Update: The BLT IS SO BOMB.

An upscale diner in the middle of Chinatown might seem out of place- but step inside and you instantly feel a sense of nostalgia. Nickel and diner did a great job of modernizing the look while still giving us the feel of a classic American diner. From the quality wooden menu clipboards to the hooks underneath the booths- I appreciate the thought that went into each and every detail. As for the food- our group ordered the egg sandwich, salmon lox and steak burger. The egg sandwich is a must try! The burger was thick and juicy but didn't feel too heavy and greasy. We wrapped up with the peanut butter chocolate cake and vanilla soft serve. Perfection. You can also grab coffee to go as they have an in-house coffee booth stationed at the front. I hear the dinner menu is even better- will definitely be back for the lunch (chicken soup) and dinner (grilled lobster and dry aged ribeye) menu!

Came here for dinner with some friends.  I had the porkchop with farro risotto.  Both were delicious.  The porkchop was perfectly cooked.  I had it medium.  Also had the fried chicken appetizer which was very good.  Ambiance was great.  Good for both groups and dates.  Would come back again.  No alcohol served though.  They are still waiting on their liquor license.

I finally have my go to brunch spot! I had the sliders and BLT with brussel sprouts and their generous portion of fries (which are to die for)! Don't leave without their chocolate chip cookie and nitro cold brew! Can't wait to try dinner!!

I've marked nickel & diner my go-to brunch spot because it is THAT delicious. The interior of the diner gives me a classic elegance and modern vibe(uh not sure how to explain that). We were greeted and seated by the hostess as soon as we walked in. I've tried the Buttermilk Pancakes,Roasted Maitake Mushrooms,Ranchero Omelette, and Salmon Lox. I absolutely LOVE LOVE LOVE the salmon lox. I am not a salmon fan BUT it was surprisingly delicious. The best part was the dessert. Kaffir key lime tart is a must order item. I will be back for dinner sometime this week! super excited. There might be a wait but it is well worth it.

I went to Nickel & Diner this weekend with high expectations for it, especially considering the Yelp reviews and a friend's recommendation. My sister had made a reservation for the both of us at 11:30 am on a Sunday. We arrived at the restaurant at 11:25 and was asked to wait. Fine, we were a few minutes early. No big deal. However, by the time 11:30 hit, we still had not been seated and other parties who had arrived as walk-ins had been seated before us. We tried not to let that bother us as we were brought to a nice big booth for the two of us. Seemed a little like a waste to seat the two of us at a booth big enough for six, but we weren't going to complain.Our waitress soon arrived after to introduce herself and poured us each a glass of tap and asked us for drink orders. However, it was only later when the table behind us sat down that I heard them being asked if they would like still, sparkling, or tap water. I'm not sure how I feel about not having been even given an option, but that's fine. Not a big deal.We soon put in our orders for Roasted Maitake Mushrooms, Classic Egg Sandwich, and a side of Potato Hash and proceeded to entertain ourselves with our phones and with conversation. However, fifteen minutes soon turned into thirty, at which point I believe our waitress stopped by to tell us that the food would be out shortly. Thirty minutes turned into forty-five minutes, and at that point, we were pretty concerned about how long we'd waited. We were really tempted to just walk out at that point (doubt we would have done it but the thought certainly crossed my mind), so it was good that our food showed up right then.By this time, we pretty much shoved our faces with the food because we were so hungry. I can't say that I would say the food was exceptional in any sort of way. It was good, but certainly not something that I would wait forty-five minutes for, especially since we consumed all three dishes in fifteen. Likely will not be coming back since I feel like there are plenty of other better options in the city to try out.

Good food - wait was horrendous. If you go expect the wait to take longer to sit down then what they tell you. I get that it's new and they are still dialing in everything, but it would have been nice if they acknowledged the wait by giving us something to snack / drink while we were waiting for our food.

This fancy diner from the Chikarashi  folks actually has no Howard St frontage far as I can tell (you enter on Centre St to a host stand on the right and a takeout counter ahead of you, with restrooms behind that). Friendly staffers took our order for the hazelnut crunch to go, which was quite good, but the bag and container were quite an excessive waste. The restroom also had no hand soap (empty bottle) and the receipt subject line is oddly from 'house account'.Hazelnut Crunch $3.50 ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Subtotal: $3.50 Total Tax: $0.31 ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: $3.81

What a great addition to the neighborhood!  Comforting diner classics with a modern chef'd up taste.  You cannot go wrong with anything on the menu!  But-- my favorite for breakfast is the Classic Egg Sandwich.  It is perfectly delicious-- served on a classic poppy seed Kaiser roll with hickory smoked bacon and country ham, two fried eggs, sharp cheddar, and a basil vinaigrette.  So good that I couldn't stop thinking about it the whole week and returned back for breakfast the following week.  Coffee here is amazing, they also do a nitro brew. If you live close by, change your morning routine and pickup your coffee here!  There is a cafe area that you can do pickups if you do not sit down to dine.  Other great breakfast meals-- Kale Cashew Bowl, if you want to be healthy.  The Roasted Maitake Mushrooms plate is amazing and the Salmon Lox won't disappoint either!  For lunch, the fried chicken is a great small plate.  The Slow Roasted Squash is shockingly delicious that you won't be able to stop eating it.  Also a great silky delicious chicken soup that will warm your soul and fill you up-- the ricotta dumplings pair it up so beautifully. The sliders are a hit and the mac and cheese is one of the best I've had!  I also spied a soft serve machine!  What's not to love? Such a gem!

Love the addition of modernized diner food in Chinatown !  Friends and I ordered the classic egg sandwich, chicken soup, pancakes, and the mushrooms!   This will be my go to spot for my almond latte fix .. AND they have nitro cold brew!!!!

My new favorite brunch place -- and I can't wait to see the dinner menu when they have one. The place isn't officially open yet for another week, but they are serving brunch and I think also lunch so far.  My friend and I had brunch today and I'll definitely go back.  I had the egg sandwich, a bargain at $8.  It comes with bacon, cheese, egg and I think ham on a Kaiser roll.  Really scrumptious.  I started with the chicken soup, which isn't much to look at but is very flavorful and has delicious ricotta filled dumplings.  (Wish they'd offer the dumplings as a menu choice by themselves.  The warm ricotta just oozed out of the middle.)  And the kefir lime tart dessert was also really appealing.  My friend had the macadamia pancakes and she liked them, although I don't think she was as wow'ed as I was.    Some other tables near us had ordered the burgers, and those looked mighty mighty fine.   As far as ambiance goes, the restaurant is airy and a bit deco in feeling.  It seemed very clean and new.  My friend called it a definite 2016 take on a diner.  A great addition to the neighborhood.Wheelchair accessibility notes:  The restroom I saw was a large single use bathroom with bars by the toilet and a mirror canted so that a wheelchair user could see him/herself.  The sink was on legs rather than cantilevered from the wall, so that might be a bit harder to use.  The hand dryer was at a level suitable for wheelchair users.  There are, however, two steps at the main entrance to get into the restaurant but a ramp at a secondary door.  The dining area is all on one level, but about 2/3 of the seating is either in booths or on elevated stools.  The North end of the restaurant has a seating area with at least 6 tables, and it would be easy to position a wheelchair to eat in that area.

Awesome new brunch spot from the Chikarashi team! Everything was delicious and executed perfectly. They pay attention to detail here and it shows in the food. My favorites are the fried chicken, brussels sprouts and the DESSERT. Must get dessert here. Wash it down with their amazing coffee. Can't wait to go back for dinner!

Sunday brunch! This new place (soft opening 10am to 4pm now) just open 10 days ago, but it was packed when we just went there for brunch around 1pm!  We both ordered sandwiches which were average.  The place is spacious and clean with simple design which I like it, it is good for 2 people or a small group of 4-5, not sure it will do dinner in the future. Guess I will go back another time to try its lunch menu or other dishes, and hopefully it will serve some other drinks  beside coffee and juice  by the time, also with better preparation of food that they ran out of food and juice I wanted to order originally, but it could be understandable due to soft opening.

Their chicken soup is the best thing to hit my mouth since 1990. Their gluten-free cookies = second best thing to hit my mouth since 1990. Gorgeous space, reasonable prices, nitro cold brew on tap. Their bathrooms are also bigger and nicer than my bedroom. Bring your squad here and thank me later
Chicken soup, maitake mushrooms, egg sandwich and hot chocolate. I've now lived a full life. Best new brunch and prices are so reasonable. Amazing.

The coffee. Had an iced almond milk latte, best I've ever had. Will be coming here daily. Oh and the booths are perfect for large parties, will be bringing my friends here over the weekend. Extremely friendly/gorgeous staff, shout out to the host who introduced himself!

Finally there's a place to go to for classic American comfort food in SOHO/Little Italy/Chinatown! Nickel & Diner is in soft opening so it's only breakfast and lunch. Definitely go for the Egg Sandwich ($8) or the Salmon Lox ($14). If you like coffee, they offer NobleTree and you will be impressed! Looking forward to returning for lunch; so glad to have found this new spot on the corner of Centre and Howard St.

Ever wonder why nostalgia compels you to eat crappy quality diner food time and time again, forcing you to tell yourself the food is "good" for the sake of tradition? Well stop wondering since you'll be abandoning your sad habit and going to Nickel & Diner from now on. Its decor and menu philosophy undoubtedly pays homage to the classic American diner experience, yet it upgrades the experience via artisanal ingredients and execution by a world-class executive chef.  Just try the sliders and think about how empty your life was before you tasted this bite of awesomeness.  Have the freshly made lemon tart along with the Nobletree Coffee and then self-flagellate for ever having eaten those stale florescent-lit diner counter desserts and instant burnt coffee. Oh and its cheap too. So go for the 3 course experience here, folks.

The nicest models serve you in a super sleek diner format redux.. There are food nods to Asian, Italian & Jewish cuisine,. Modern, clean with booths and a bar with old fashioned stools, this corner joint is stunning. There are updated comfort classics.I came for lunch during the soft opening and this will be a sure fire hit!Ate:Seared diver scallops with warm beet vinaigrette & pumpkin seed quince $11Baby Brussels sprouts with Shisitos peppers preserved lemon and crispy sunchokes $8The scallops were lovely, but just two at lunch barely satisfied. The Brussels sprouts & shisitos needed an aioli or dipping sauce, the dish was a tad dry . There is little value here, but lots of fun, sceney like a Chinatown version of the venerable Coffee Shop sans the 'tude.

Fresh off the major success of Chikarashi, the same team just opened Nickel & Diner, a slick new diner around the corner.Much like at Chikarashi, everything here is excellent. They are currently serving just breakfast and lunch, but will open later soon for dinner. For lunch, there are a bunch of excellent sandwiches, especially the Pressed Veal Breast Ruben ($15).There is also a coffee bar up front that will start serving cold brew next week, and dessert staring soon, so I'll definitely be back often.
